orbotix.sphero
Class Sphero

java.lang.Object
  java.util.Observable
      orbotix.robot.base.Robot
          orbotix.sphero.Sphero
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Closeable
public class Sphero
extends Robot

Sphero is the world's first robotic ball that you control with a tilt, touch, or swing from your smartphone or tablet. You can drive Sphero, play tabletop and multiplayer games, hold Sphero in your hand to use it as a controller for on-screen gameplay, learn basic programming, and even explore augmented reality. WHAT WILL YOU BUILD!!!

Method Detail

startCalibration

public void startCalibration()
Start the aiming routine. Enable the back LED.

stopCalibration

public void stopCalibration(boolean acceptCalibration)
End the calibration routine

Parameters:
acceptCalibration - true to set current Sphero heading to 0 degrees, false to cancel.

drive

public void drive(float heading,
                  float velocity)
Drive the robot

Parameters:
heading - from 0-360 in degrees where 180 degrees is pointing in the direction of Sphero's blue tail light the heading increases in the clockwise direction and rolls over at 359 degrees.
velocity - 0.0 - 1.0 where 0.0 is stopped and 1.0 is full speed.

stop

public void stop()
Stop rolling, but maintain the current heading

setColor

public void setColor(int red,
                     int green,
                     int blue)
Set the main color of the robot: RGB values from 0 (off) to 255 (full intensity)

Parameters:
red - The red value from 0 (off) to 255 (full intensity).
green - The green value from 0 (off) to 255 (full intensity).
blue - The blue value from 0 (off) to 255 (full intensity).

setBackLEDBrightness

public void setBackLEDBrightness(float brightness)
Set the back LED brightness
  • 0 = off
  • 1 = full brightness

Parameters:
brightness - 0.0 (off) to 1.0 (full brightness)

Returns:
Configuration control

enableStabilization

public void enableStabilization(boolean stabilize)
Enable/Disable internal stabilization of Sphero, in which the IMU is used to match the ball's orientation to its various set points. Stabilization is enabled by default when Sphero powers up. Disable stabilization when using Sphero as an external input controller or even to save battery power during testing that doesn't involve movement (orbBasic, etc.)

Parameters:
stabilize -

getSensorControl

public SensorControl getSensorControl()
Setup Sensor data streaming listeners:
  • Orientation - Quaternion
  • Orientation - Euler (roll, pitch, yaw)
  • Accelerometer
  • Gyro
  • Location
  • Velocity

Returns:

sleep

public void sleep(int wakeInSeconds)
Parameters:
wakeInSeconds - The time in seconds to wake the robot up. 0 seconds indicates that the robot will never wake up. see {#link sleep()}

Disconnect from the robot.

rotate

public void rotate(float heading)
Rotate in place. Change the current heading without changing location.

Parameters:
heading - will rotate to this orientation (in degrees)

setRotationRate

public void setRotationRate(float maxRateInDegreesPerSecond)
Deprecated. 

Control the rotation rate that Sphero will use to meet new heading commands. A lower value offers better control but with a larger turning radius. A higher value will yield quick turns but Sphero may roll over on itself and lose control. Max Value = 400 d/s Zero doesn't make much sense so it's interpreted as 1, the minimum

Parameters:
maxRateInDegreesPerSecond -

sendRawByteCommand

public void sendRawByteCommand(byte[] rawData)
Send a raw byte command to Sphero. Only use this method if you know how to form a proper command per the Sphero API doc

Parameters:
rawData - the byte array of command to send to Sphero
